chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Balanitis - adults
chapter.summary: Covers the management of suspected or confirmed balanitis in young men and adults 16 years of age and older in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards (Male).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage an adult with balanitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a young man or adult has suspected balanitis:

  • Advise the person to clean under the foreskin daily with lukewarm water and to dry it gently.
    • Do not use soap or bubble bath which may irritate the area.
    • Consider an emollient (such as emulsifying ointment) as a soap substitute.
  • Advise on sources of written information and support, such as:
    • The NHS information leaflet on Balanitis.
    • The Patient.info information leaflet on Balanitis.
  • For suspected non-specific dermatitis:
    • Prescribe topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment once a day and an imidazole cream, the frequency depending on the preparation used, until symptoms settle or for up to 14 days.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
      • See the section on Topical imidazoles in the section on Prescribing information for more information.
      • Advise that topical imidazole preparations may damage latex condoms and diaphragms.
  • For suspected irritant or allergic contact dermatitis:
    • Advise the person to stop any suspected triggers (such as soap, bubble bath, latex condoms, lubricants, or creams).
    • Prescribe topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment once a day until symptoms settle, or for up to 14 days.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
    •  Advise on the use of a regular emollient and use as a soap substitute. See the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact for more information.
  • For suspected or confirmed candidal balanitis:
    • Prescribe an imidazole cream, the frequency depending on the preparation used, until symptoms settle or for up to 14 days, or
    • Prescribe oral fluconazole 150 mg as a single dose
      • See the sections on Topical imidazoles and Oral fluconazole in the section on Prescribing information for more information.
      • Advise that topical imidazole preparations may damage latex condoms and diaphragms.
    • If inflammation is causing discomfort, consider prescribing topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment for up to 14 days in addition.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
    • If there is confirmed recurrent candidal balanitis:
      • Consider advising on testing for Candida infection in any sexual partner(s), to reduce the potential reservoir of infection. See the CKS topic on Candida - female genital for more information, if appropriate.
  • For suspected or confirmed bacterial balanitis:
    • Prescribe oral flucloxacillin 500 mg four times a day for seven days. If the person is allergic to penicillin, prescribe oral clarithromycin 250 mg twice daily for seven days.
      • See the sections on Flucloxacillin and Clarithromycin in the section on Prescribing information for more information.
    • If inflammation is causing discomfort, consider prescribing topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment for up to 14 days in addition.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
    • If there is confirmed recurrent Streptococcal balanitis:
      • Consider advising on testing for Streptococcal infection in any sexual partner(s), to reduce the potential reservoir of infection.
  • For suspected or confirmed anaerobic (Gardnerella) balanitis:
    • Prescribe oral metronidazole 400 mg twice a day for seven days.
      • See the section on Metronidazole in the section on Prescribing information for more information.
    • If inflammation is causing discomfort, consider prescribing topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment for up to 14 days in addition.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
    • If there is confirmed recurrent Gardnerella balanitis:
      • Consider advising on testing for Gardnerella infection in any sexual partner(s), to reduce the potential reservoir of infection. See the CKS topic on Bacterial vaginosis for more information, if appropriate.
  • For suspected seborrhoeic dermatitis, see the CKS topic on Seborrhoeic dermatitis for more information on management.
  • For suspected genital psoriasis, see the CKS topic on Psoriasis for more information on management.
  • For a suspected or confirmed sexually transmitted infection, arrange referral to a sexual health clinic or manage in primary care, as appropriate.
  • For all other possible underlying causes of balanitis, or if there is any uncertainty regarding the diagnosis, arrange specialist referral for further assessment and management. 
  • If symptoms are not improving following seven days of initial treatment:
    • Stop treatment with topical hydrocortisone (if using).
    • Take a sub-preputial swab to exclude or confirm a fungal or bacterial infection, and treat accordingly. Be aware that:
      • Group B streptococcus is usually a commensal and does not usually need treatment.
      • Candida may be a superadded infection and its presence does not exclude an underlying skin condition.
  • Arrange a blood test for HbA1c to assess for underlying diabetes mellitus and HIV (if appropriate), if balanitis is severe, persistent, or recurrent (especially if candidal balanitis is present). See the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1, Diabetes - type 2, and HIV infection and AIDS for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are largely based on expert opinion in the 2013 European guideline for the management of balanoposthitis [Edwards, 2014], expert opinion in the Royal College of General Practitioners and British Association of Sexual Health and HIV (RCGP/BASHH) publication Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [Lazaro, 2013], expert opinion in review articles on male genital skin conditions [English et al, 1997; Shim, 2016] and on penile inflammatory skin disorders [Morris, 2017].

  • CKS found no evidence for the comparative effectiveness of different topical imidazole preparations for the management of balanitis.
  • The information on imidazole creams potentially damaging condoms is based on expert opinion in the European guideline [Edwards, 2014], the RCGP/BASHH publication [Lazaro, 2013], and expert opinion in the British National Formulary [BNF 74, 2017].
  • The recommendation to offer testing for Candida infection in sexual partners of men with confirmed recurrent candidal balanitis is based on expert opinion in the European guideline [Edwards, 2014] and in the RCGP/BASHH publication [Lazaro, 2013], as there is a high rate of candidal infection in sexual partners which may act as a reservoir for reinfection.
  • The recommendation on the use of flucloxacillin for suspected or confirmed bacterial balanitis is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice, as this antibiotic has activity against group A beta-haemolytic streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus. It is also based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendation to offer testing for Streptococcus in sexual partners of men with confirmed recurrent Streptococcal balanitis is based on the fact that the primary reservoir for group B beta-haemolytic streptococci is the female genital tract, and sexual transmission is the most likely cause of streptococcal balanitis [English et al, 1997].
  • The recommendation to offer testing for Gardnerella infection in sexual partners of men with confirmed recurrent Gardnerella balanitis is based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendations on the significance of culture of group B streptococcus and candida following sub-preputial swabbing are based on expert opinion in the RCGP/BASHH publication [Lazaro, 2013] and the European guideline [Edwards, 2014].
  • The recommendation on considering and assessing for causes of immunosuppression such as diabetes mellitus and HIV if balanitis is severe or persistent is based on expert opinion in the European guideline [Edwards, 2014] and in a review article [Morris, 2017].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer an adult with balanitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange referral to a dermatologist, sexual health specialist, or urologist, depending on the most likely underlying cause using clinical judgement, if:
    • The diagnosis is uncertain.
    • Balanitis is persistent and does not respond to initial management in primary care.
    • Balanitis is recurrent and associated with inability to retract the foreskin (phimosis) — refer to a urologist for consideration of circumcision.
    • Balanitis is recurrent and no underlying cause is found.
    • There is suspected allergic contact dermatitis — refer to a dermatologist for consideration of patch testing. See the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact for more information.
    • There is suspected Zoon's balanitis — a penile biopsy may be needed to exclude a pre-malignant condition, which may present similarly.
    • There is suspected lichen sclerosus — specialist assessment may be needed as there is a small risk of malignant transformation.
    • There is a suspected sexually transmitted infection (STI) — refer to a sexual health clinic for further assessment and management.
    • There is a penile mass or ulcerated lesion, where an STI has been excluded as a cause, or there is a persistent penile lesion after treatment for an STI has been completed — to exclude a pre-malignant penile condition or penile malignancy. See the CKS topic on Urological cancers - recognition and referral for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral are based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015], expert opinion in the 2013 European guideline for the management of balanoposthitis [Edwards, 2014], expert opinion in the Royal College of General Practioners and British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (RCGP/BASHH) publication Sexually Transmitted Infections in Primary Care [Lazaro, 2013], the British Association of Dermatologists' (BAD) Guidelines for the management of lichen sclerosus 2010 [BAD, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article on benign male genital skin conditions [Shim, 2016].

  • If balanitis is persistent and does not respond to initial management in primary care, a penile biopsy may be needed to exclude pre-malignant or malignant disease [Edwards, 2014; Shim, 2016].
  • Lichen sclerosus needs specialist followup as there is a risk of malignant transformation (male genital lichen sclerosus is associated with about 50% of cases of penile squamous cell carcinoma) [Lazaro, 2013; Shim, 2016]. It may also lead to complications such as phimosis, meatal stenosis, or urethral stricture, which may require surgical management such as circumcision, meatotomy, or urethroplasty [BAD, 2010; Edwards, 2014; Shim, 2016].
  • Any new warty or papular lesions, persistent ulcers, erosions, hyperkeratosis, and fixed erythematous areas in men with genital lichen sclerosus or lichen planus need specialist referral to exclude malignant change [BAD, 2010; Shim, 2016].
